Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi Jeff,

You ask some interesting questions. See below.



> That makes se=
nse. So now my questions are this:
> 1) Do these vectors of standard deviat=
ions evolve in the usual sense? I.e.
> does selection act on the performanc=
e on the problem, and the vector of SDs
> hitchhike along for the ride?
>

=
Yes, since the individuals that pass on to the next generation are not
comp=
rised only by their usual parameters, but they contain their strategy
param=
eters as well (SDs).



2) Has anyone shown that these self-adapted SDs are=
 better than leaving
> them at a fixed size (on rugged fitness landscapes: =
note that the sphere
> function is not rugged)? I=E2=80=99d like to see a s=
weep across different
> fixed-sizes to find the long-term optimum, and then=
 see if self-adapted SDs
> outperform the best of those. My hypothesis is t=
hat the self-adaptation is
> extremely maladaptive (again, provided that th=
e problem is non-trivial).
> I=E2=80=99ve asked people in the ES community =
for similar papers, but have never
> seen one produced.
>

I don't come fro=
m the field of ES, so I am not sure. I haven't seen such a
paper. I noticed=
 though that often people benchmark their algorithms on
noisy versions of s=
ome fitness functions (e.g., a noisy sphere function).
Noise creates a kind=
 of rugged landscape, right?




> 3) If CMA-ES is self-adapting its mutati=
on rate in a way that helps: why?
> My paper lays out intuitive reasons for=
 why we should expect mutation rates
> to evolve to be low and hurt long-te=
rm performance (because evolution is
> focusing on the short-term average f=
itness, not the long-term average
> fitness). So why doesn=E2=80=99t this r=
easoning apply to CMA-ES?
>


> That is also my understanding of how it wor=
ks in tradition ES. But I
> thought it worked differently in CMA-ES. For ex=
ample, I don=E2=80=99t think
> individuals in CMA-ES are mutated versions o=
f their parents. I think they
> are freshly drawn from the learned distribu=
tions. And I don=E2=80=99t think
> offspring are kept, but are only used to=
 update the learned distributions.
> But as I said, my knowledge of CMA-ES =
sis fuzzy. Partly because I don=E2=80=99t
> understand it perfectly, it=E2=
=80=99s hard for me to see if there is some mechanism
> that allows self-ad=
aptation to work well.
>

In the previous email I was mostly talking about =
ES. You are right that
CMA-ES works differently. The mean individual is cal=
culated using weighted
recombination. I don't understand CMA-ES perfectly e=
ither, so you've got me
thinking. I think now that CMA-ES does not exactly =
use self-adaptation in
the normal sense, since it uses something called cum=
ulative step adaptation
(CSA), also known as cumulative path length control=
. CSA does not use local
mutation steps, but a record of fading mutation st=
eps, known as evolution
path or search path, which carries information abou=
t the relation between
single steps.

I read that this evolution path can i=
mprove the adaptation and search
procedure remarkably. Do you think it can =
be seen as a way to mitigate the
problem of long-term adaptation?



So fit=
ness does impact which SDs survive? That does sound like
> self-adaptation,=
 making me skeptical about whether it really works.
>

Yes, in self-adaptiv=
e ES (not CMA-ES), fitness does impact which SDs
survive and selection is d=
eterministic / rank-based.




> Thanks for the clarification. It=E2=80=99s=
 an interesting, important question and
> I=E2=80=99m glad we=E2=80=99re tr=
ying to get to the bottom of it.
>

In summary, I now think that self-adapt=
ive ES might not perform very well
for long-term adaptation, while CSA (whi=
ch is not the same as self-adaptive
mutation rates) is a way to make the al=
gorithm perform better.



Best,
Vassilis

--bcaec529974582a11104f8e3a967

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
